ruleset.name: Unnecessary
ruleset.description: The Unnecessary Ruleset contains a collection of rules for unnecessary code.

rule.name: UnnecessaryConversionTemporary
rule.message: Avoid unnecessary temporaries when converting primitives to Strings
rule.description: Avoid the use temporary objects when converting primitives to Strings. Use the static conversion methods on the wrapper classes instead.

rule.name: UnnecessaryReturn
rule.description: Avoid the use of unnecessary return statements.

rule.name: UnnecessaryFinalModifier
rule.message: Unnecessary final modifier in final class / private methods
rule.description: When a class has the final modifier, all the methods are automatically final and do not need to be tagged as such. Similarly, methods that can't be overridden (private methods, methods of anonymous classes, methods of enum instance) do not need to be tagged either.

rule.name: UselessOverridingMethod
rule.description: The overriding method merely calls the same method defined in a superclass.

rule.name: UselessOperationOnImmutable
rule.message: An operation on an Immutable object (String, BigDecimal or BigInteger) won't change the object itself
rule.description: An operation on an Immutable object (String, BigDecimal or BigInteger) won't change the object itself since the result of the operation is a new object. Therefore, ignoring the operation result is an error.

rule.name: UnusedNullCheckInEquals
rule.message: Invoke equals() on the object you''ve already ensured is not null
rule.description: After checking an object reference for null, you should invoke equals() on that object rather than passing it to another object's equals() method.

rule.name: UselessQualifiedThis
rule.message: Useless qualified this usage in the same class.
rule.description: Look for qualified this usages in the same class.

rule.name: UnnecessaryModifier
rule.message: Avoid modifiers which are implied by the context
rule.description: Fields in interfaces and annotations are automatically `public static final`, and methods are `public abstract`. Classes, interfaces or annotations nested in an interface or annotation are automatically `public static` (all nested interfaces and annotations are automatically static). Nested enums are automatically `static`. For historical reasons, modifiers which are implied by the context are accepted by the compiler, but are superfluous.
